Democracy issue oF today's meeting
Undefeated Jays meet Swarthmore tomorrow Council kills
When the whistle blows at 2:30
tomorrow afternoon, spectators at
Homewood field will see two of the
strongest small school teams that
have ever played there swing into
action. Hopkins in its first home
game this season will be on edge
for its seventh straight football win,
while the Swarthmore invadors with
a tough schedule behind them have
their teeth set for revenge for the
manhandling the Blue fed them
last season. With Swarthmore rated
extremely strong and highly improved, the game promises to be a powerhouse duel.
Judging by past performances,
Jakle, Swarthmore's triple threat
man, ought to give Coach Malonnee's hopefuls plenty of trouble and
worry In other games this season
Jackle has demonstrated his ability
as a passer, kicker, and runner, having been Swarthmore's leading gainer both by land and air. In addition,
Wolfe, the Garnets' right halfback, is a powerhouse on the line,
particularly in off-tackle plays.
Right down the line, the Pennsylvanians have a heavy, but fast team.
Their line averages about 190 lbs
while the backfield averages about
175 lbs.
It wouldn't be true to say that the
Jays have any outstanding stars. In

their only two games played the
boys have demonstrated very capably and convincingly their ability to
work as a team. Instead of having
only one passer, the Jays can use
Spilman, ace booter, Maxcy, and, at
times, Rudo and Kerstetter, whereas
all four men are hard driving, plunging backs.
The Jay line will be outweighed
as it was in its previous battles.this
season. However, the line has already
proved itself capable offensively and
defensively with the only scoring
against the team having been made
via the airways. The front line has
so far been fortuitously free from
serious injuries, fear of which the

William Lamble ...

The Hullabaloo Board of control
announced this week that a circulation drive will Start on Monday, November 7. The board said, "We feel
sure that the Hulabaloo of 1939 has
something outstanding to offer to
the whole student body. The purpose
of a drive at this time is to increase
our undergraduate circulation. If we
are assured of a circulation of over
400 books to the lower classes, we
will use undergraduate photographs."
Only those students, seniors and unundergraduates, who subscribe to the
book will be included."
At the present time the circulation of the book has passed the 200
mark. All students, who have not
subscribed, will be approached within the two-week period of the drive.
This year marks the golden anniversary of the annual at the Hopkins. It was in 1889 that the first
Hullabaloo was produced. Ted Schad,
editor of the 1939 book stated that
staff will commemorate the fiftieth
anniversary of the Hullabaloo in
theme, make-up, and general presentation."
The budget of the HullabaZoo has
been expanded considerably so the
students will have a book of which
to be proud. J Henry Blucher, circulation manager said, "Remember,
the Hullabaloo is your annual and it
is your job to support it as much as
any other activity on the campus.
Let's see every student sign up and
be one of the lucky ones to appear
in the book."

arrested by

Results of the freshman class elections are being withheld, pending action by the Student council at its
meeting today. This step was taken
by the 'Council after it had received
that printed material

information

was being circulated at the polls by
candidates.
Several weeks ago the 'Council issued a decree outlawing the use of
printed matter as campaign material. Despite this specific warning,
several violations came to the attention of the council which promptly
outlawed the elections.
Today the council will decide whether the first results will be admitted.

'Pygmalion' at Guild
George Bernard Shaws Pygmalion
is being presented for the last times
tonight and tomorrow night by the
Play-Arts Guild at its little theater
on 22nd street.
Mr T M Cushing, managing
director of the Guild, is a graduate of
the Hopkins and one of the founders
of the Hopkins Play Shop. The Guilders will continue their fall presentations next week with a revival of the
Gilbert and Sullivan operetta Utopia
Limited.
Reduced prices have been arranged
for Hopkins students.

with luncheon
Members of the freshman class
will have their second formal view of
Dr Isaiah Bowman tomorrow afternoon, when Omicron Delta Kappa,
national honorary activities fraternity, sponsors a luncheon at Levering
hall. The program will feature an
address by Dr Bowman and the singing of Hopkins songs. Several faculty members, alumni, as well as the
entire freshman class, have been invited.
The announcement of this project
marks the debut of the honor
society in campus affairs for this
year. Besides its function of rewarding accomplishment in activities,
0 D K is designed to provide leadership in backing activities which deserve student support
The Beta Circle of the Omicron
Delta Kappa at the Johns Hopkins
University was established in 1916.
Qualifications for membership include, "Character and distinguished
leadership in one or more of the
following branches, scholarship, athletics'
) publications, dramaticst and
forensic activities." Only three per
cent of the undergraduate body is
eligible for selection to the society
during the undergraduate year.
At present, six men compose the
fraternity. They include president
Bob Anderson, and members Harold
Rydstrom,
Dr
Ricards,
Buddy
Mark Secrist, William Mehling and
Murray Kempton.

IStormers need female talent;
seek it at Goucher college
By S S S
Girls, girls, girls—female ones—
were the crying need of the Barnstormers as they met at the Barn
for first try-outs last Tuesday.
An invitation has been sent to
Goucher college as a probable source
of talent for the corning 'Stormer
show, and it is expected that they
will render the necessary support.
Miss Bunny Harris, of Goucher,
was offered a screen test by one of
the three big film companies when
she played the ingenue lead in the
Stormer production of Once in a Life
Time two years ago.
Howard Lindsay's She Loves Me
Not is in line with the Barnstormer
policy of presenting recent Broadway hits. The show will be presented
at the Auditorium theater on the

evening of December 17 A dance will
be held at Levering hall following
the performance.
Coach John E Desch urged all men
interested in trying out for parts to
attend the next rehearsal on Tuesday night at 7:30 in the Barn. No
roles have yet been filled. Desch described She Loves Me Not as a "satire on college life with a dash of
chorus girls murder, and Hollywood
maniacs".
Sam Greenstein and his production crew will begin work this week
on the twenty scenes that the script
requires. The business staff this year
is functioning under Bob Anderson.
"Butch" McShane, president of the
'Stormers, expressed satisfaction with
the first try-outs but hopes for a
larger turnout at the next rehearsal.

Victory lest Followed by 'big name' band planned
By EDGAR KASSAN
While announcing plans for a Victory ball on Saturday, November 12,
the Board of social activities yesterday gave definite reassurrances that
they will sponsor a 'name band' dance
afer Chrismas.
The assertion may be considered
as a reply to William Lamble, chairman of the purged Cotillion board
who while urging support for his
petition last week stated, "Naturally
I hope the Hopkins students want
'name bands' and will vote in favor
of the Cotillion board, which is their
only chance of getting them." Don
Kirkwood, chairman of the Board of
social activities,'would make no statement on Lamble's petition last week.

Bob Craig and his orchestra have
been signed for the Victory ball which
Will be promoted in Latrdbe hall.
Beginnino- at 9 p m and terminating
at 1 a fli, the affair will follow the
Hopkins-Alle,'-any football contest
in the afternoon. The admission price
will be 50 cents per person.
The board was forced to avert from
the customary nrocedure of using
Levering hall AL all home social
affairs, as the ballmarn had already
been procurred for the evening.
Latrobe's dance floor is larger, however, and will be a better site if the
attendance is large.
"Considering the success of the
football team and the prospect of a
big dance early in the new year,"

By LEONARD QUITT
The current issue of democracy on
the campus, aroused originally by exCotillion board member Lamble,
comes to a head today in a mass
meeting in front of Levering at 1:00
o'clock. The mass meeting is labelled
"a protest to Dean Berry's statement", published in the NEWS LETTER
last week, a statement in which the
Dean anticipated Council action of
yesterday in denying recall of the
Cotillion board question in General
assembly.
In back of today's meeting is a
committee of mogul and semi-mogul
representatives of the ASU, the exCotillion board, the NEWS-LETTER,
and various fraternities. Acting
chairman is Kenneth F Maxey,
managing editor of the NEWS-LETTER
and quarterback on the Hopkins Varsity. The m eeting itself is in
the nature of consideration of
yesterday's petition which "requested student government in extra-curricular non-athletic activity", and
takes the form of speeches delivered
by representative members of the
group comprising the committee.
The attitude of the Student council
towards the affair seems one of
watchful waiting. Said Harold
Ricards, "Considering all facts and
acting in the best interests of the entire Student body, including the
petitioners themselves, the Council
has agreed that there will be ao
General assembly or consideration of
the Cotillion board question.
However, Boots Kaufman, representing the AiSU indicates that the
issue of democracy on the campus
supercedes the bare Cotillion board
question. "As a matter of pure principal," says Kaufman, "it seems imperative that something should be
done to secure self-government for
the Student Body."
Most unusual aspect of today's
meeting is its sponsorship, for on the
committee are members of the exCotillion board, accused of being the

declared Kirkwood, "we may expect
a large attendance and can promise
everyone an enjoyable evening."
Craig's orchestra and their locally
prominent vocalist, Shirley Dewlow,
will perform on the band stand in
the decorated hall. Attire will be
semi-formal.
Prospects of a successful affair are
considerably bolstered by recollections
of the freshman-sophomore dance
held in Latrobe two years ago. It was
the most successful lowerclass affair
sponsored during the term.
Members of the Board of social
activities 'beside Kirkwood are Arthur
Maass, Bucky Sellman, John Driscoll,
George L Miller, and the president of
the freshman class (not yet elected).

The council, then, should assume control over the
activities program. In its management, the experience
and wisdom of administration officials will be valuable.
But the ultimate decision belongs by right to the student body.
The campus has other problems. We are all genuinely
concerned with questions of curriculum and tuition,
matters by right the administration's exclusive
province. In such matters, the Council should stand up
to its duty of expressing the will of the student body
before the Dean and the Board of Trustees.
Within such a pattern, then, we will have a genuine
student government. Wherever possible, the sentiment
of the undergraduate body will be the single criterion
—for action. And where such control is impracticable, the
campus will have a forthright representative before
the authorities.
More than anything else at this moment we need
to understand the responsibilities and problems of selfgovernment. We are set out on the road which will
lead ultimately to the reclamation of our democratic
heritage. But it will require clear eyes and a steady
hand to get there.

an army of half a million untrained
men in the war of 1812 and for seven
years to triple the previous entire
yearly expenditures of our government, in order to resist an army of
16,500; nor was this belated effort
enough to save the city of Washington from capture and the torch.
More history: Barely four thousand Americans died in the Revolution. More than two thousand one
hundred Frenchmen were killed in
that same war. We put Franco's system of "volunteers" in the shade; I
don't think it was an American
revolution at all. By the standards
now applied to Spain, it was a French
invasion.
Leftists will vouch for the accuracy
of an AP dispatch from Barcelona
saying that the cathedral had been
struck by one of Franco's bombs.
The item went on, very casually, to
say that the church had been closed
and barred since war broke out, and
a sign was on it saying that the
people's government had taken it
over for their own use. I suppose it
held valuable stores of vacuum, or
was a concentration camp for ghosts;
if they say that this barred and empty
building had been bconfiscated for use,
what faithless few shall deny it?
Every argument in this column is
a challenge; every unanswered challenge I must regard as a victory. This
paper has a "Letters to the Editor"
department, use it. Only an intellectual weakling is afraid to justify himself by written arguments. If the shoe
fits, sue me.

Adolescent Activities—Ill
In line with the current campus
revolt is the newest fad adopted by
the present crop of Hopkins moguls.
We refer to the sudden appearance
of pea shooters at Homewood.
Our first intimation of the prevalance of these deadly weapons was
forcibly brought home last Monday
when we were attacked by no less
than four myrmidons in the space of
ten minutes. And after retreating to
the questionable security of the library we were just in time to see
one of the librarians shriek with
wrath at the impact of a pellet with
her posterior.
So, in anticipation of the undergraduate call to arms, which now appears imminent, we have cornered the
total available supply of pea-shooters and firmly expect to reap a tidy
profit in the near future.

A pound of blood
Collective bargaining, according to
our latest report from the front, has
now entered the Hippocratic realm.
Our medical correspondent informs
us that a rise in the cost of blood
transfusions from $7 to $10 per cc
is a sure thing within the next few
months. Reason: a bl000d-donors
union has been chartered by the A
F of L, Clashes between the organized donors and blood bureau officials
appear imminent.
According to Charles Vonie A F
of L organizer, the new union is
pledged to refrain from strikes, provide free blood for the medically indigent, and always be guided by "the
best interests of society."
Our correspondent says, however,
that the world's champion blood donor stands aloof from this clamor.
He is Philadelphia's 60-year-old
strong man, Edward Howard. He has
given 881 transfusions free and hopes
to give one thousand.
Our informant vows that Howard
drives ten-penny nails into oak planks
with his fist, and then pulls them
out by his teeth.

"I began my lacrosse career at
City College under the dynamic instruction of Herman Epstein" said
John Tolson, Hopkins All American
lacrosse player. John was sitting in
a chair, his legs crossed, his arms
folded and his head back.
He told us the story of his lacrosse
career. In 1935, his first year at City
College, John was fortunate enough
to make the varsity first team wing
defense. This is a tough position for
a 15 year old, tall, and lanky fellow
to hold. In the course of the season
he injured his spine and was forced
to drop out for the rest of the season and to remain in bed for nine
months.
Because of his injury he could not
take part in Eppie's 1935 championship team. However, in 1936, wearing
a brace on his back he returned to
the old Indian game, hardy and full
of vim and vigor, ready to aid Eppie
to another championship.
"This time, I took over the close-in
Post," said John, looking ever so
often over to Evans Sith who was
writing something on the blackboard.
"After winning the state championship we climaxed that season with
a trip to New York and the National
Lacrosse championship. The next season I returned as a veteran to the
team. Again we won the national
championship. That ended my career
at City College."
John forgot to mention that both
years that he played he was picked
on the All Maryland high school team
as best bet. Last year, playing as a
freshman on the Hopkins first team,
he was given All American mention.
After the interview we turned to
what Evans had written on the blackboard, it was his own interview on
himself.
"Nine years ago, as I was walking
down Roland Avenue with my baseball glove under my arm, John Tolson
attacked me with his crutch which
I later found to be a lacrosse stick.
Realizing how impotent a baseball
mitt was as a means of a defense,
from that day on I took up the noble
sport of lacrosse. Since that time, I
have grown from a 98 lb weakling
to an 180 lb Atlas. Never again have
I had cause to fear man or beast. I
credit John Tolson's bullying instinct with showing me the way to
become a man through the use of
lacrosse weapons."

Phi Psi's grid warriors set a new
high in Hopkins Interfraternity football competition last week when they
virtually anihilated the Phi Eps, 68-0.
The outcome was never in doubt as
Phi Psi scored on the first play of
the game with shifty Bucky Sellman carrying the mail.
From then on, it was a matter of
how many points Phi Psi could possibly score in 40 minutes of playing
time. Completing long passes from
Tolson to Follmer or Smith; beautiful runs by Sellman; an alert secondary which intercepted the Phi Ep
passes and converted them into touchdowns, illustrates in a few words the
story of the game. The victory for
Phi Psi makes them oustanding favorites to retain the football title which
they captured last year.

"I believe that without the reassertion of religion as the supreme
factor in the determination of human
destinies, mankind will revert to a
world in which the passions and the
appetites of the animal will reign
supreme and the divine light of the
spirit will be quenched," stated Under-secretary of state Sumner Welles
in addressing a large gathering at the
religious lecture Tuesday evening at
Latrobe hall.
Using religion as a basis for his
talk, Mr Welles bitterly attacked the
loss of religious faith in the world
today which has contributed to a
cruel and ruthless policy on the part
of nations in Europe towards helpless minorities. He praised the Bill of
Rights for its guarantee of freedom
to the people.
In speaking of the foreign policy
of the country, Mr Welles criticized
a program of strict isolation from the
rest of the world. Speaking of the
policy of non-involvement and nonentanglement, he said, "Problems
and disputes of the world are not so
narrow as to require us to shut our
eyes and seal our lips in smug
security in our own country."
He took issue with those who are
condemning the government for its
failure to enunciate its foreign policy
in clear and unequivocal language
and said:
"We stand for limitation of armaments by the principal powers and
for ourselves. An army and navy sufficiently strong to enable us to defend
ourselves against attack only and not
for aggression. Reciprocal understandings with other countries will
remove trade barriers and accord
mutual economic benefits."
Mr. Welles also stressed the importance of a reaffirmation of a religious faith which he claims is the only
way that the world can combat the
ever growing wave of intolerance and
remove the ever existent danger of
war.

Yin condemns
Jap policy
Fir Pao-Yu Yin, professor of polica1 science at Nanking university,
spoke at Levering hall last Wednesday, ascribing the present Sino-Japanese war to Japan's policy of conquest and empire building, growunrest, and the threat
ing
of revolution in Japan. The talk
highlighted an informal reception for
Dr Yin and Miss Pearl Teh-Wei Liu,
the Chinese delegates to last summer's World Youth Congress.
Attacking Japan's official reasons
for the invasion of China as false,
Dr Yin accused the aggressor of reintroducing the wide spread of
opium, and of destroying China's
cultural institutions so as to keep
the Chinese an ignorant subject
race.
"In 1937," said Dr Yin, "80% of
the Japanese farms were in debt,
wages dropped 20%, and the cost of
living rose 25%. This economic crisis made an immediate foreign war
necessary, and brought into operation Japan's program of world empire through domination of the Pacific ocean."
The Chinese have won the war already, in strategy it was claimed by
Dr Yin. "We are bewildered by the
sight of our greatest friend sending
supplies to Japan, but we feel that if
we are able to keep on fighting we
will be able to exhaust Japan's finan-

... how fast that
says itfor smokers...refreshing mildness.•. better taste
more pleasing aroma...
everything you could ask for in
a cigarette

cial resources."
It was the 1931 invasion of China,
asserted Dr Yin, which set a precedent for the events in Ethiopia,
Austria, and Czechoslovakia. "Those
incidents would not have followed if
Manchuria had been settled in a different way."
Despite his generally optimistic
view of China's future, Dr Yin declared. "The end of the war may mean
destruction of two peoples and their
work of centuries." '
Miss Liu, formerly a Shanghai
school teacher, followed Dr Yin with
a short sketch of the part played by
Chinese women in the defense of
their country, and an appeal to the
women of America to boycott silk
stockings. The speakers were introduced by Mr B P Kang, graduate
student in engineering.

Undefeated Jays meet Swarthmore tomorrow Council kills
When the whistle blows at 2:30
tomorrow afternoon, spectators at
Homewood field will see two of the
strongest small school teams that
have ever played there swing into
action. Hopkins in its first home
game this season will be on edge
for its seventh straight football win,
while the Swarthmore invadors with
a tough schedule behind them have
their teeth set for revenge for the
manhandling the Blue fed them
last season. With Swarthmore rated
extremely strong and highly improved, the game promises to be a powerhouse duel.
Judging by past performances,
Jakle, Swarthmore's triple threat
man, ought to give Coach Malonnee's hopefuls plenty of trouble and
worry In other games this season
Jackle has demonstrated his ability
as a passer, kicker, and runner, having been Swarthmore's leading gainer both by land and air. In addition,
Wolfe, the Garnets' right halfback, is a powerhouse on the line,
particularly in off-tackle plays.
Right down the line, the Pennsylvanians have a heavy, but fast team.
Their line averages about 190 lbs
while the backfield averages about
175 lbs.
It wouldn't be true to say that the
Jays have any outstanding stars. In

their only two games played the
boys have demonstrated very capably and convincingly their ability to
work as a team. Instead of having
only one passer, the Jays can use
Spilman, ace booter, Maxcy, and, at
times, Rudo and Kerstetter, whereas
all four men are hard driving, plunging backs.
The Jay line will be outweighed
as it was in its previous battles.this
season. However, the line has already
proved itself capable offensively and
defensively with the only scoring
against the team having been made
via the airways. The front line has
so far been fortuitously free from
serious injuries, fear of which the

hard hitting backfield, Captain Bill
Day hopes to lead his team on to

William Lamble ...

The Hullabaloo Board of control
announced this week that a circulation drive will Start on Monday, November 7. The board said, "We feel
sure that the Hulabaloo of 1939 has
something outstanding to offer to
the whole student body. The purpose
of a drive at this time is to increase
our undergraduate circulation. If we
are assured of a circulation of over
400 books to the lower classes, we
will use undergraduate photographs."
Only those students, seniors and unundergraduates, who subscribe to the
book will be included."
At the present time the circulation of the book has passed the 200
mark. All students, who have not
subscribed, will be approached within the two-week period of the drive.
This year marks the golden anniversary of the annual at the Hopkins. It was in 1889 that the first
Hullabaloo was produced. Ted Schad,
editor of the 1939 book stated that
staff will commemorate the fiftieth
anniversary of the Hullabaloo in
theme, make-up, and general presentation."
The budget of the HullabaZoo has
been expanded considerably so the
students will have a book of which
to be proud. J Henry Blucher, circulation manager said, "Remember,
the Hullabaloo is your annual and it
is your job to support it as much as
any other activity on the campus.
Let's see every student sign up and
be one of the lucky ones to appear
in the book."

IStormers need female talent;
seek it at Goucher college
By S S S
Girls, girls, girls—female ones—
were the crying need of the Barnstormers as they met at the Barn
for first try-outs last Tuesday.
An invitation has been sent to
Goucher college as a probable source
of talent for the corning 'Stormer
show, and it is expected that they
will render the necessary support.
Miss Bunny Harris, of Goucher,
was offered a screen test by one of
the three big film companies when
she played the ingenue lead in the
Stormer production of Once in a Life
Time two years ago.
Howard Lindsay's She Loves Me
Not is in line with the Barnstormer
policy of presenting recent Broadway hits. The show will be presented
at the Auditorium theater on the

evening of December 17 A dance will
be held at Levering hall following
the performance.
Coach John E Desch urged all men
interested in trying out for parts to
attend the next rehearsal on Tuesday night at 7:30 in the Barn. No
roles have yet been filled. Desch described She Loves Me Not as a "satire on college life with a dash of
chorus girls murder, and Hollywood
maniacs".
Sam Greenstein and his production crew will begin work this week
on the twenty scenes that the script
requires. The business staff this year
is functioning under Bob Anderson.
"Butch" McShane, president of the
'Stormers, expressed satisfaction with
the first try-outs but hopes for a
larger turnout at the next rehearsal.

The assertion may be considered
as a reply to William Lamble, chairman of the purged Cotillion board

petition last week stated, "Naturally
I hope the Hopkins students want
'name bands' and will vote in favor
of the Cotillion board, which is their
only chance of getting them." Don
Kirkwood, chairman of the Board of
social activities,'would make no statement on Lamble's petition last week.

Bob Craig and his orchestra have
been signed for the Victory ball which
Will be promoted in Latrdbe hall.
Beginnino- at 9 p m and terminating
at 1 a fli, the affair will follow the
Hopkins-Alle,'-any football contest
in the afternoon. The admission price
will be 50 cents per person.
The board was forced to avert from
the customary nrocedure of using
Levering hall AL all home social
affairs, as the ballmarn had already
been procurred for the evening.
Latrobe's dance floor is larger, however, and will be a better site if the
attendance is large.

NIP

By LEONARD QUITT
The current issue of democracy on
the campus, aroused originally by exCotillion board member Lamble,
comes to a head today in a mass
meeting in front of Levering at 1:00
o'clock. The mass meeting is labelled
"a protest to Dean Berry's statement", published in the NEWS LETTER
last week, a statement in which the
Dean anticipated Council action of
yesterday in denying recall of the
Cotillion board question in General
assembly.
In back of today's meeting is a
committee of mogul and semi-mogul
representatives of the ASU, the exCotillion board, the NEWS-LETTER,
and various fraternities. Acting
chairman is Kenneth F Maxey,
managing editor of the NEWS-LETTER
and quarterback on the Hopkins Varsity. The m eeting itself is in
the nature of consideration of
yesterday's petition which "requested student government in extra-curricular non-athletic activity", and
takes the form of speeches delivered
by representative members of the
group comprising the committee.
The attitude of the Student council
towards the affair seems one of
watchful waiting. Said Harold
Ricards, "Considering all facts and
acting in the best interests of the entire Student body, including the
petitioners themselves, the Council
has agreed that there will be ao
General assembly or consideration of
the Cotillion board question.
However, Boots Kaufman, representing the AiSU indicates that the
issue of democracy on the campus
supercedes the bare Cotillion board
question. "As a matter of pure principal," says Kaufman, "it seems imperative that something should be
done to secure self-government for
the Student Body."
Most unusual aspect of today's
meeting is its sponsorship, for on the
committee are members of the exCotillion board, accused of being the
(Page 4, Please)

declared Kirkwood, "we may expect
a large attendance and can promise
everyone an enjoyable evening."
Craig's orchestra and their locally
prominent vocalist, Shirley Dewlow,
will perform on the band stand in
the decorated hall. Attire will be
semi-formal.
Prospects of a successful affair are
considerably bolstered by recollections
of the freshman-sophomore dance
held in Latrobe two years ago. It was
the most successful lowerclass affair
sponsored during the term.
Members of the Board of social
activities 'beside Kirkwood are Arthur
Maass, Bucky Sellman, John Driscoll,
George L Miller, and the president of
the freshman class (not yet elected).

The council, then, should assume control over the
activities program. In its management, the experience
and wisdom of administration officials will be valuable.
But the ultimate decision belongs by right to the student body.
The campus has other problems. We are all genuinely
concerned with questions of curriculum and tuition,
matters by right the administration's exclusive
province. In such matters, the Council should stand up
to its duty of expressing the will of the student body
before the Dean and the Board of Trustees.
Within such a pattern, then, we will have a genuine
student government. Wherever possible, the sentiment
of the undergraduate body will be the single criterion
—for action. And where such control is impracticable, the
campus will have a forthright representative before
the authorities.
More than anything else at this moment we need
to understand the responsibilities and problems of selfgovernment. We are set out on the road which will
lead ultimately to the reclamation of our democratic
heritage. But it will require clear eyes and a steady
hand to get there.

of the Revolution, our
army was reduced to eighty men, because standing armies were considered a waste and a menace to democracy; our geographic isolation was
to protect us. Therefore, as a result
of this peace policy, such as is still
urged today, we were forced to raise
an army of half a million untrained
men in the war of 1812 and for seven
years to triple the previous entire
yearly expenditures of our government, in order to resist an army of
16,500; nor was this belated effort
enough to save the city of Washington from capture and the torch.
More history: Barely four thousand Americans died in the Revolution. More than two thousand one
hundred Frenchmen were killed in
that same war. We put Franco's system of "volunteers" in the shade; I
don't think it was an American
revolution at all. By the standards
now applied to Spain, it was a French
invasion.
Leftists will vouch for the accuracy
of an AP dispatch from Barcelona
saying that the cathedral had been
struck by one of Franco's bombs.
The item went on, very casually, to
say that the church had been closed
and barred since war broke out, and
a sign was on it saying that the
people's government had taken it
over for their own use. I suppose it
held valuable stores of vacuum, or
was a concentration camp for ghosts;
if they say that this barred and empty
building had been bconfiscated for use,
what faithless few shall deny it?
Every argument in this column is
a challenge; every unanswered challenge I must regard as a victory. This
paper has a "Letters to the Editor"
department, use it. Only an intellectual weakling is afraid to justify himself by written arguments. If the shoe
fits, sue me.

At last someone has written an
anti—Nazi play. "Waltz in

Goose

Step", which opened on Broadway
Tuesday, is an open attack against
the Fascist system of central Europe.
Oliver Garret, the author, wrote the
story in the hope that it will arouse
the people against such .a form of
government. His theory is that the
public will heed more to the warnings
of a play than they will to the pleas
of a magazine article. Although no
open reference is made to any country or dictator, the inference is so
clear that no one can doubt that the
locale is Germany and the leader,
Hitler.
It seems as though the Mercury
theatre will continue to frighten the
American public. After causing mass
hysteria by their "too realistic" radio
dramatization of H G Wells' "The
War of The Worlds," the cast is now
appearing before Gotham audiences
in a script on the French revolution.
Orson Welles and the rest of the
boogey men are all on hand to take
care of the folks they missed.

Adolescent Activities—Ill
In line with the current campus
revolt is the newest fad adopted by
the present crop of Hopkins moguls.
We refer to the sudden appearance
of pea shooters at Homewood.
Our first intimation of the prevalance of these deadly weapons was
forcibly brought home last Monday
when we were attacked by no less
than four myrmidons in the space of
ten minutes. And after retreating to
the questionable security of the library we were just in time to see
one of the librarians shriek with
wrath at the impact of a pellet with
her posterior.
So, in anticipation of the undergraduate call to arms, which now appears imminent, we have cornered the
total available supply of pea-shooters and firmly expect to reap a tidy
profit in the near future.

A pound of blood
Collective bargaining, according to
our latest report from the front, has
now entered the Hippocratic realm.
Our medical correspondent informs
us that a rise in the cost of blood
transfusions from $7 to $10 per cc
is a sure thing within the next few
months. Reason: a bl000d-donors
union has been chartered by the A
F of L, Clashes between the organized donors and blood bureau officials
appear imminent.
According to Charles Vonie A F
of L organizer, the new union is
pledged to refrain from strikes, provide free blood for the medically indigent, and always be guided by "the
best interests of society."
Our correspondent says, however,
that the world's champion blood donor stands aloof from this clamor.
He is Philadelphia's 60-year-old
strong man, Edward Howard. He has
given 881 transfusions free and hopes
to give one thousand.
Our informant vows that Howard
drives ten-penny nails into oak planks
with his fist, and then pulls them
out by his teeth.

C

We can't vouch for the verity of
this story but it's too good to pass
up.
We have it that the Pep committee's chairman, Bernstein, who is
also an R 0 T C man and has a
Napoleonic complex of gargantuan
proportions, thought it would be a
good idea to make the RO TC a
subsidiary of the pep committee.
With this in mind he printed an
order addressed to the entire student corps stating that all enlisted
men should report for the pep parade without guns.
This got back to G H Q where the
big-wigs promptly hit the ceiling.
When they landed they asked in a
loud voice who in the hell was the
pep committee and what it had to do
with the U S government?
At the present time the whereabouts of Bernstein is unknown.

Good little man
The Barnstormers are to be congratulated upon their choice of John
E Desch for this year's coaching job.
Although he only stands about
five feet, four on a stool, Desch ranks
as one of the best little-theatre directors below the Mason-Dixon line. If
he can produce another Once in a
Lifetime the Barnstormers will have
something to cheer about. Here's
hoping.

Swarthmore in a attempt to stretch
victory to three straight for the '38
season. (Speaking of Swarthmore
. . . it's a beautiful school which carries in its carriculum a better than
average grade of coeds.) But back to
business at hand- . . . Among its student body is a gent named Jakle. He's
been toting the pigskin for the garnet
eleven and literally taking it places.
The last time he was in the mood to
give for dear old Swarthmore was
just last Saturday . . . when he lugged the ball over the line just three
times against Hamilton college.
He Runs, Kicks and Passes
The garnet captain is one of these
characters in football known as a
"triple threat" star; which, as we
all know, means he runs, passes and
kicks. If the Bluejay team can figure out what he's going to do and
smear his attempts ,the Black and
Blue can expect a victory. However,
if the garnet player is in the mood to
do more than just work up an appetite for supper, the Jays are in for
a afternoon of good, hard football.
Black and Blue Have Backs To Spare
Hopkins on the other hand have a
goodly supply of speedy backs considering the size of the squad. Jack
McNally has fourteen backs to work
with, who are expected to kick up a
lot of dust tomorrow. The outstanding Jay Weakness is its lack of reserve linesmen. As long as the line
can stand the pace, there isn't too
much to be feared from any of the
Hopkins opponents this season. However, with only about ten first string
linesmen available, an injury or bad
break anywhere in this group would
be fatal. The less said concerning a

"I began my lacrosse career at
City College under the dynamic instruction of Herman Epstein" said
John Tolson, Hopkins All American
lacrosse player. John was sitting in
a chair, his legs crossed, his arms
folded and his head back.
He told us the story of his lacrosse
career. In 1935, his first year at City
College, John was fortunate enough
to make the varsity first team wing
defense. This is a tough position for
a 15 year old, tall, and lanky fellow
to hold. In the course of the season
he injured his spine and was forced
to drop out for the rest of the season and to remain in bed for nine
months.
Because of his injury he could not
take part in Eppie's 1935 championship team. However, in 1936, wearing
a brace on his back he returned to
the old Indian game, hardy and full
of vim and vigor, ready to aid Eppie
to another championship.
"This time, I took over the close-in
Post," said John, looking ever so
often over to Evans Sith who was
writing something on the blackboard.
"After winning the state championship we climaxed that season with
a trip to New York and the National
Lacrosse championship. The next season I returned as a veteran to the
team. Again we won the national
championship. That ended my career
at City College."
John forgot to mention that both
years that he played he was picked
on the All Maryland high school team
as best bet. Last year, playing as a
freshman on the Hopkins first team,
he was given All American mention.
After the interview we turned to
what Evans had written on the blackboard, it was his own interview on
himself.
"Nine years ago, as I was walking
down Roland Avenue with my baseball glove under my arm, John Tolson
attacked me with his crutch which
I later found to be a lacrosse stick.
Realizing how impotent a baseball
mitt was as a means of a defense,
from that day on I took up the noble
sport of lacrosse. Since that time, I
have grown from a 98 lb weakling
to an 180 lb Atlas. Never again have
I had cause to fear man or beast. I
credit John Tolson's bullying instinct with showing me the way to
become a man through the use of
lacrosse weapons."

Phi Kappa Psi blows lid off
with 68 point touch record
Phi Psi's grid warriors set a new
high in Hopkins Interfraternity football competition last week when they
virtually anihilated the Phi Eps, 68-0.
The outcome was never in doubt as
Phi Psi scored on the first play of
the game with shifty Bucky Sellman carrying the mail.
From then on, it was a matter of
how many points Phi Psi could possibly score in 40 minutes of playing
time. Completing long passes from
Tolson to Follmer or Smith; beautiful runs by Sellman; an alert secondary which intercepted the Phi Ep
passes and converted them into touchdowns, illustrates in a few words the
story of the game. The victory for
Phi Psi makes them oustanding favorites to retain the football title which
they captured last year.
In a little less spectacular but
more exciting fracas, Kappa Alpha
nosed out the fighting Alpha Delts
in a well-played contest12-6.
The K A's worked the ball down
the field after several exchanges of
punts, mixing tricky reverses with
a long pass which put them in scoring
position. On the last down, Radford
took a 10 yard pass from Kohlhoff
and scampered the few remaining
yards for the score.
The K A's came right back and
scored again, after the A D's failed
to gain, when Schneider started on
a left-end run, turned and threw a
long pass to Ward who was waiting
in the right flat for the toss. The
play caught the whole A D secondary
off guard, and Ward just trotted over
the goal line.
The A D score came two plays
from the end of the game when Penniman spotted O'Neill's pass, intended for Ward, and raced over into
pay-off territory for the final score
of the game. Kohlhoff, Ward and
O'Neill were oustanding for K A

"I believe that without the reassertion of religion as the supreme
factor in the determination of human
destinies, mankind will revert to a
world in which the passions and the
appetites of the animal will reign
supreme and the divine light of the
spirit will be quenched," stated Under-secretary of state Sumner Welles
in addressing a large gathering at the
religious lecture Tuesday evening at
Latrobe hall.
Using religion as a basis for his
talk, Mr Welles bitterly attacked the
loss of religious faith in the world
today which has contributed to a
cruel and ruthless policy on the part
of nations in Europe towards helpless minorities. He praised the Bill of
Rights for its guarantee of freedom
to the people.
In speaking of the foreign policy
of the country, Mr Welles criticized
a program of strict isolation from the
rest of the world. Speaking of the
policy of non-involvement and nonentanglement, he said, "Problems
and disputes of the world are not so
narrow as to require us to shut our
eyes and seal our lips in smug
security in our own country."
He took issue with those who are
condemning the government for its
failure to enunciate its foreign policy
in clear and unequivocal language
and said:
"We stand for limitation of armaments by the principal powers and
for ourselves. An army and navy sufficiently strong to enable us to defend
ourselves against attack only and not
for aggression. Reciprocal understandings with other countries will
remove trade barriers and accord
mutual economic benefits."
Mr. Welles also stressed the importance of a reaffirmation of a religious faith which he claims is the only
way that the world can combat the
ever growing wave of intolerance and
remove the ever existent danger of
war.

Yin condemns
Jap policy
Fir Pao-Yu Yin, professor of polica1 science at Nanking university,
spoke at Levering hall last Wednesday, ascribing the present Sino-Japanese war to Japan's policy of conquest and empire building, growunrest, and the threat
ing
of revolution in Japan. The talk
highlighted an informal reception for
Dr Yin and Miss Pearl Teh-Wei Liu,
the Chinese delegates to last summer's World Youth Congress.
Attacking Japan's official reasons
for the invasion of China as false,
Dr Yin accused the aggressor of reintroducing the wide spread of
opium, and of destroying China's
cultural institutions so as to keep
the Chinese an ignorant subject
race.
"In 1937," said Dr Yin, "80% of
the Japanese farms were in debt,
wages dropped 20%, and the cost of
living rose 25%. This economic crisis made an immediate foreign war
necessary, and brought into operation Japan's program of world empire through domination of the Pacific ocean."
The Chinese have won the war already, in strategy it was claimed by
Dr Yin. "We are bewildered by the
sight of our greatest friend sending
supplies to Japan, but we feel that if
we are able to keep on fighting we
will be able to exhaust Japan's finan-

It was the 1931 invasion of China,
asserted Dr Yin, which set a precedent for the events in Ethiopia,
Austria, and Czechoslovakia. "Those

Despite his generally optimistic
view of China's future, Dr Yin declared. "The end of the war may mean
